outrunners.title: OutRunners

sources.description: Web research - no specific rotation data found

Supermodel emulator community confirms 270 degrees

sources.description: Supermodel emulator and Thrustmaster setup guide confirm 270 degrees

nightdriver.title: Night Driver

sources.description: Wikipedia paddle controller article - confirms potentiometer-based steering

nightdriver.notes: One of earliest first-person racing games. Wikipedia confirms paddle wheel mechanically coupled to potentiometer. 4-position gear shift and accelerator pedal.

offroadchallenge.title: Off Road Challenge

sources.description: Same cabinet/wheel assembly as Cruis'n World and SF Rush

offroadchallenge.notes: Same cabinet as Cruis'n World and SF Rush. Motorized FFB steering. Midway V-Unit hardware. SuzoHapp 270-degree wheel.

roadburners.title: Road Burners

sources.description: Standard motorcycle arcade cabinet handlebar range

roadburners.notes: Motorcycle racing with tilting motorcycle cabinet. Handlebar rotation ~45 degrees total, combined with lean input. Up to 8 players linkable.

roadsedge.title: Roads Edge

sources.description: Manual auto-center description indicates pot-based 270-degree system

roadsedge.notes: First racer on Hyper Neo Geo 64. Custom Driving Board with analog steering. Auto-centers during boot (potentiometer-based). Up to 4 linkable.

sfrush2049se.title: San Francisco Rush 2049 Special Edition

sources.description: SuzoHapp parts catalog for Rush 2049 cabinets

sfrush2049se.notes: Software upgrade to Rush 2049 cabinets. SuzoHapp 270-degree FFB wheel. Sit-down with 4-speed shifter and 3 pedals.

slipstream.title: Slip Stream

sources.description: Sega System 32 platform standard

slipstream.notes: Extremely rare F1 game (~150 units) on Sega System 32. Only non-Sega game on this hardware. 270 based on System 32 platform standard.

spyhunter2.title: Spy Hunter II

sources.description: Era-standard assumption for 1980s driving games

spyhunter2.notes: Shared cabinet with Max RPM. Two-player split screen with two wheels, pedals, shifters, weapon buttons. 270 estimated from era standard.

superspeedracejr.title: Super Speed Race Junior

sources.description: MAME dial input type and Speed Race series optical encoder lineage

superspeedracejr.notes: Final game in Taito's Speed Race series (since 1974). MAME lists as dial (optical encoder). Top-down perspective.

streetdrivin.title: Street Drivin'

sources.description: Hard Drivin' series hardware - 10-turn potentiometer

streetdrivin.notes: Unreleased prototype, Race Drivin' sequel. Same Hard Drivin' cabinet with 10-turn potentiometer and ~3 rotation stop.

topsecret.title: Top Secret

sources.description: Standard pot-based range assumption

topsecret.notes: Spy driving/shooting on Exidy 440. Conversion kit for Crossbow cabinets with add-on steering wheel. Custom interface board for steering.

worldrally.title: World Rally

sources.description: Arcade Museum forum - PCB jumper for 270/360 degree wheel selection documented

worldrally.notes: PCB jumper selects between 270-degree potentiometer and 360-degree optical wheel. Standard config is 270-degree pot. 23,000 units sold in Europe.

xtremeally.title: Xtreme Rally

sources.description: Manual auto-center/calibration description plus Roads Edge platform continuity

xtremeally.notes: Hyper Neo Geo 64. Sequel to Roads Edge. FFB auto-centers during boot. Manual warns not to touch steering during Network Check (self-calibration). Up to 4 linkable.

acedriver.title: Ace Driver

sources.description: Namco System 22 calibration thread on BYOAC

acedriver.notes: Namco System 22. Continuous rotation potentiometer, no spring return. 10-inch red leather racing wheel. FFB motor. Same platform as Ridge Racer.

raveracer.title: Rave Racer

sources.description: Namco System 22 platform standard - same as Ridge Racer

raveracer.notes: Third Ridge Racer entry, Namco System 22. Adds FFB over Ridge Racer 2. Same platform and steering as Ridge Racer and Ace Driver.

steeringchamp.title: Steering Champ

sources.description: Era-standard assumption for steering wheel arcade games

steeringchamp.notes: Part of Bishi Bashi series (Handle Champ in Japan). Collection of 17 car-themed minigames. Konami 573 hardware. Not a traditional racing game.

longbeach.title: Long Beach

sources.description: No documentation found - extremely obscure

longbeach.notes: Extremely rare Italian-made top-down driving game. No known surviving units. Zero documentation found.

wheelsandfire.title: Wheels & Fire

sources.description: Conflicting control information - may not use steering wheel

wheelsandfire.notes: Obscure Spanish-made racing game. arcade-history.com lists joystick control despite MAME paddle classification. May use joystick not wheel.

acedrivervictorylap.title: Ace Driver: Victory Lap

sources.description: Namco Ace Driver Victory Lap Operator Manual on ManualsLib
Namco System 22 standard 270-degree potentiometer (same as Ridge Racer, Ace Driver, Rave Racer)

acedrivervictorylap.notes: Namco System 22. Sequel to Ace Driver. 10-inch Mountney steering wheel with FFB motor. No spring self-centering. Standard Namco 270-degree potentiometer.

nash_racing.notes: Indie racer. Generic controller support. No specific wheel/FFB documentation. Mixed reviews (47%).

project_drift.title: Project Drift

sources.description: Steam store page research
Manga-style JDM drift game. 540 aligns with JDM drift genre standard.

project_drift.notes: Manga-style JDM drift game. Full controller support listed but no specific wheel mentions. Gamepad-focused.

absolute_drift.title: Absolute Drift

sources.description: Steam community research
Community consensus: 900 too high, 400-500 recommended. 450 midpoint for responsive top-down drift control.

absolute_drift.notes: Top-down minimalist drift game. Zen Edition added some wheel support (G27/G29). Basic vibration. Not a traditional sim.

star_wars_episode_i_racer.title: STAR WARS Episode I Racer

sources.description: Steam community research
Pod racing (1999/2018 re-release). Supports DirectX FFB. 270 matches era standard.

star_wars_episode_i_racer.notes: Pod racing (1999/2018 re-release). Supports DirectX FFB devices per original specs. Mixed results with modern wheels.

drift_type_c.title: Drift Type C

sources.description: Steam store page research
Physics-based multi-discipline driving. 540 balances drift responsiveness with racing precision.

drift_type_c.notes: Physics driving game (Early Access). Gamepad recommended. Wheel+FFB was planned feature. Implementation status unclear.

initial_drift_online.title: Initial Drift Online

sources.description: Steam community research
F2P multiplayer touge drift racing. Real Initial D arcade cabinets use 540.

initial_drift_online.notes: F2P multiplayer drift racing on mountain passes. Logitech wheel support in Beta. Not all wheel types supported.

ocean_city_racing.title: OCEAN CITY RACING

sources.description: Steam store page research

ocean_city_racing.notes: Open-world driving game. No wheel or controller support evidence. Appears keyboard/mouse focused.

drive_beyond_horizons.title: Drive Beyond Horizons

sources.description: Steam community, developer statements

drive_beyond_horizons.notes: Procedural open-world driving sim (Early Access). NO wheel or controller support yet. Devs say wheel support planned.

toybox_turbos.title: Toybox Turbos

sources.description: Steam community research

toybox_turbos.notes: Top-down Micro Machines-style racer. No wheel support. Delisted from Steam.

death_rally_classic.title: Death Rally (Classic)

sources.description: Steam store page research

death_rally_classic.notes: 1996 top-down DOS combat racer. Keyboard only. No wheel or FFB.

death_rally.title: Death Rally

sources.description: Steam store page research

death_rally.notes: Top-down combat racer (2012 remake). Designed for gamepad/touchscreen (mobile port). No wheel or FFB.

kanjozoku_game.title: Kanjozoku Game

sources.description: Steam community research

kanjozoku_game.notes: Street racing/drift MMO. Community threads confirm NO wheel support. Controller/keyboard only.

heading_out.title: Heading Out

sources.description: Steam community research

heading_out.notes: Narrative road-movie racing. No wheel support. Driving mechanics too sluggish for wheel use.

trail_out.title: TRAIL OUT

sources.description: Developer statement

trail_out.notes: FlatOut-style vehicular combat racer. Dev confirmed NO wheel/FFB. 'We have an arcade game, not a simulator.'

crashmetal_cyberpunk.title: CrashMetal - Cyberpunk

sources.description: Steam store page research

crashmetal_cyberpunk.notes: Open-world cyberpunk drift racer. Claims controller support but poorly implemented. No confirmed wheel support.

art_of_rally.title: art of rally

sources.description: Steam community discussions confirm wheel works via xinput but no FFB; 540 degrees recommended by multiple T300/T150 users

art_of_rally.notes: Designed primarily for gamepad/keyboard. Wheels work via xinput but no force feedback (Unity engine limitation). 540 degrees is community consensus.

rush_rally_3.title: Rush Rally 3

sources.description: Developer-posted Steam discussion confirms DirectInput 8 wheel support with FFB. Recommended 540-720 degree rotation.

rush_rally_3.notes: Wheel support via DirectInput 8 with force feedback. Developer recommends 540-720 degrees. Logitech G923/G920/G29 and Thrustmaster confirmed working.

new_star_gp.title: New Star GP

sources.description: Steam discussions and developer comments confirm limited wheel support for Logitech G29 and Thrustmaster T150/T300. No force feedback.

new_star_gp.notes: Retro-style F1 racing game. Very limited wheel support added post-launch. Steering feels digital rather than analog. No FFB. Developer acknowledges wheel support is limited.

beach_buggy_racing_2.title: Beach Buggy Racing 2: Island Adventure

sources.description: Developer response on Steam confirms no steering wheel support. Multiple changes would be needed for wheel experience.

beach_buggy_racing_2.notes: Kart racer. Developer explicitly confirmed no wheel support on PC. Standard gamepads and keyboard only.

parking_garage_rally_circuit.title: Parking Garage Rally Circuit

sources.description: Developer stated wheel works if recognized as game controller. Has deadzone/sensitivity settings. No explicit FFB confirmation.

parking_garage_rally_circuit.notes: Lo-fi Sega Saturn-inspired rally game. Wheel works via generic game controller input. Has sensitivity and deadzone adjustment.

offroad_mania.title: Offroad Mania

sources.description: No dedicated wheel support found. One user reported game crashes on launch when Logitech G29 is connected.

offroad_mania.notes: Off-road 4x4 driving simulator with puzzle-like levels. Wheel support appears absent or broken - crash reports with G29 connected.

rfactor.title: rFactor

sources.description: Steam community guide recommends 450 degrees as good middle ground; configurable via Controller.ini Steering Wheel Range setting

rfactor.notes: Classic PC sim racer. 450 degrees recommended as most car mods won't use steering lock above 30 degrees. RealFeel FFB plugin recommended over default.

gtr_2.title: GTR 2: FIA GT Racing Game

sources.description: OverTake.gg thread confirms GTR 2 is hard-wired to 240 degrees FFB wheel rotation; cannot be changed

gtr_2.notes: GTR 2 has a hard-wired 240 degree wheel rotation that cannot be changed. Set physical wheel to 240 degrees for 1:1 match.

my_winter_car.title: My Winter Car

sources.description: Steam community discussions confirm wheel support with visual rotation matching setting. 900 degrees matches Logitech G29 physical range.

my_winter_car.notes: Open-world car life simulator. Has in-game wheel rotation setting to match physical wheel. Some users report alignment issues (~30 degree offset).

drifto_infinite_touge.title: Drifto: Infinite Touge

sources.description: No specific wheel support documentation found. Full controller support confirmed on Steam store page.

drifto_infinite_touge.notes: Drift-focused touge racing game. Full controller support but no documented wheel-specific information.

slipstream_ansdor.title: Slipstream

sources.description: Steam community confirms no native wheel support; no control remapping options in-game

slipstream_ansdor.notes: Retro pseudo-3D arcade racer inspired by OutRun. No native steering wheel support. Keyboard/gamepad only.

18_wheeler_midway.title: 18 Wheeler (Midway)

sources.description: Identified from MAME catver.ini as driving game with paddle input

18_wheeler_midway.notes: Early driving game. Uses paddle control. Not to be confused with Sega's 18 Wheeler (2000).

magical_truck_adventure.title: Magical Truck Adventure

sources.description: Sega Model 3 platform uses SPG-2002 steering assembly with 270 degree range

magical_truck_adventure.notes: Sega Model 3 driving game. Children's fantasy truck-driving game.
